page.title: 13ASTON-BY-STONE VILLAGE
page.content: The piece of land on which Aston stands forms part of the flood plain on the south-west bank of the River Trent. It is therefore generally quite flat and level at about 90 m. above sea level. The River Trent meanders its way through the pastures that border it, with the Trent & Mersey Canal running alongside it to the north-west. The land rises slightly to the south of the river and on the higher land is the village of Aston. It must have been a settled estate in Saxon Times, for it figures in the Norman Domesday Book, which spells it 'Estona'. This was when the estate was given by William the Conqueror to Robert de Toeni who changed his name to Robert de Stafford. Aston Village is a dormitory village for people working on local farms and in the nearby towns of Stafford and the Potteries with access via the A.51 & 34
